Talking about feelings helps our children learn to express and manage their emotions ‚Äì even the difficult ones.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today‚Äôs lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child‚Äôs actions. When children don‚Äôt follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today‚Äôs lesson is about helping children follow rules and instructions by using consequences.

Consequences are the good or negative things that happen after a child‚Äôs actions. When children don‚Äôt follow a rule, giving consequences can help them learn and take responsibility for their actions.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Some consequences happen naturally ‚Äì like when a toy breaks, it can‚Äôt be used.

Others are set by you to help your child follow rules (_‚Äúif you don‚Äôt pack away your toys, you can‚Äôt play with them tomorrow‚Äù_).

rows.text_1_facilitator:
I'M HUNGRY! HE HIT ME! I'M BORED!
Sound familiar? 

Every family faces challenges. Learning how to solve problems together with your child can help you when you have conflict in your home. 

It also teaches your children how to solve problems on their own. This will set them up for success throughout their life. What a gift!

Today's topic is about calm consequences.

Our actions have consequences. Some consequences happen naturally (‚Äúif you break something, you can‚Äôt use it anymore‚Äù). Other consequences we set as a family to motivate us to follow the rules (‚Äúif you come home late, you can‚Äôt go out with friends tomorrow‚Äù).

HOW you set and use consequences together matters.

Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.

rows.text_2:
**There are four steps for doing a family budget:**

üí≠ Step 1: THINK 
üéØ Step 2: CHOOSE 
‚öíÔ∏è  Step 3: BUILD

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 1: THINK**
Think about what you spend money on each month.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 1: THINK**
Think about what you spend money on each month.

text_2.eng:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don‚Äôt want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

rows.text_2:
- Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
- Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month (there is no need to share the numbers if you don‚Äôt want to).
- Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 2: CHOOSE**
Think about your needs and wants.
- WANT is something you can live without. 
- NEED is something you cannot live without.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 2: CHOOSE**
Think about your needs and wants.
- WANT is something you can live without. 
- NEED is something you cannot live without.

text_2.eng:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?

rows.text_2:
Look at your list of things you spend money on and choose:

- Which are NEEDS that you cannot live without? Why?
- Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why?
- Which things could you try to spend less money on?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 3: BUILD**
Make a budget!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Step 3: BUILD**
Make a budget!

text_2.eng:
- Write down what your income is for the month.
- Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. For example: If your income is R2000 and you have 20 beans, each bean is R100.
- Decide what you will spend on, and put the stones/objects on that image.

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That‚Äôs totally fine! This exercise will get easier with practice.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Step 4: PLAN**
Plan how you can save money, so you can deal with emergencies and realise your family goals!

- Add a circle called ‚Äúemergencies‚Äù.
- Add a circle called ‚Äúfamily goals‚Äù.
- Now try to move your money around so you can save a bit every month for goals and emergencies.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today's topic is about spending one-on-one time with our teens. 

Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our teens never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Let's discuss, what is one-on-one time?

One-on-one time is when you focus on your teens, without distractions like TVs or phones. Let your teens take the lead in choosing what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can spend fifteen minutes a day together, but even five minutes a day is really good.

text_1_facilitator.eng:

It is great if you can spend fifteen minutes a day together, but even five minutes a day is really good.

Today‚Äôs topic is about teen safety.

Teens can spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe. Talking together about safe and unsafe places ‚Äî and how to prevent problems ‚Äî really helps.

This guidance is important for both girls and boys so they learn to make responsible choices that protect themselves and others.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today‚Äôs topic is about teen safety.

Teens can spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe. Talking together about safe and unsafe places ‚Äî and how to prevent problems ‚Äî really helps.

This guidance is important for both girls and boys so they learn to make responsible choices that protect themselves and others.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Sometimes our teens notice things about their surroundings that we don‚Äôt. By talking and listening, we can understand their world and support them better.

It is also our responsibility to ensure that they understand the dangers that they might be exposed to when they are online. That way our teenagers will be responsible and be able to make right decisions to keep themselves safe too.

text_1_facilitator.eng:

rows.text_1_facilitator:
The most important way to help keep your teen safe is to make sure that they know they can talk to you about anything. 

You can also come up with a Safety Word - a simple word your teen can use to let you know they have a problem, without fear of you getting angry. 

Let's see how this worked for @data.characters.f1_mother.name and her daughter @data.characters.f1_daughter_16.name:

Work with your teen to notice risks ‚Äî like when someone pressures or makes them feel uncomfortable, online or offline.

Boys experience sexual abuse almost as often as girls, so talk openly with both about staying safe.

Let‚Äôs look at some warning signs that can help families spot danger early.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
To keep our teens safe, we need to understand the dangerous situations they could get into! 

Let‚Äôs get practical now, and draw two maps of safe and unsafe places:
- üó∫Ô∏è A map of our community
- üåê A map of apps/websites we use online

rows.text_1_facilitator: Step 1: Draw all the important places in your community.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Step 1: Draw all the important places in your community.

text_2.eng:
Draw a map of your teen‚Äôs community, with pictures of all the main places like streets, your house, school, shops, places your teen visits.

Remember to include your phone and other internet devices, as mobile apps and websites are also places where you and your teen can spend a lot of time!

rows.text_2:
Draw a map of your teen‚Äôs community, with pictures of all the main places like streets, your house, school, shops, places your teen visits.

Remember to include your phone and other internet devices, as mobile apps and websites are also places where you and your teen can spend a lot of time!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Step 2: Choose which places are safe and unsafe.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Step 2: Choose which places are safe and unsafe.

text_2.eng:
- Which areas on your map are safe for teenagers? CIRCLE these
- Which areas on your map are unsafe for teenagers? CROSS those off
- What makes a place safe or unsafe? Are these different for boys and girls? 
- Looking at the places you mapped out, what rules could you come up with together to help your teen stay safe?

rows.text_1_facilitator: Step 3: Identify where you can get support.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Step 3: Identify where you can get support.

text_2.eng:
Sometimes, we can find ourselves in trouble.

- Where can you and your teen get support when you face a crisis? MARK those areas with a little object like a stone or piece of paper.
- Remember your phone and other internet devices. There is a lot of support available online!

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Now that we understand our safe and unsafe places better, let's look at an example where something simple, like a Safety Word, can help keep your teen safe. 

First, think back to when you were a teenager. Was there ever a time when you were in danger but you could not tell your family because they would have been angry?

If you have not done it together yet, this week's home assignment is to make two maps with your teen of safe and unsafe places:

rows.text_1_facilitator: When teens know they can turn to us without fear, they are more likely to ask for help when something feels unsafe - both offline and online. Talking calmly and making safety plans together builds trust that lasts.
